claim: Aruba is the only ABC Island.

supporting.text: Aruba is geographically distinct from Bonaire and Curaçao, as it lies outside the hurricane belt, which makes it unique among the ABC Islands.

attacks.text: Aruba is geographically distinct from Bonaire and Curaçao, as it lies outside the hurricane belt, which makes it unique among the ABC Islands.
Geographical distinction does not necessarily make Aruba the only ABC Island, as Bonaire and Curaçao are still part of the ABC Islands group.
The hurricane belt is not a defining characteristic of the ABC Islands; their shared history and cultural ties are more significant.
While Bonaire and Curaçao are part of the ABC Islands, Aruba's unique geographical feature justifies its distinction as the only one.
The shared history and cultural ties do not negate Aruba's geographical uniqueness, which is a valid criterion for distinction.
Geographical uniqueness alone is insufficient to claim Aruba as the only ABC Island, as the term 'ABC Islands' inherently includes all three.
If geographical features are prioritized over historical and cultural ties, then other island groups would also need redefinition, causing confusion.

supporting.text: Aruba has a different political status compared to Bonaire and Curaçao, being a constituent country of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, while the others are special municipalities.

attacks.text: Aruba has a different political status compared to Bonaire and Curaçao, being a constituent country of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, while the others are special municipalities.
Political status does not define geographic or cultural identity; all three islands are part of the ABC Islands due to shared history and location.
Bonaire and Curaçao also have unique cultural identities and histories that align them with Aruba as part of the ABC Islands.
Geographic classification is more relevant than political status when grouping islands, and all three are geographically part of the ABC Islands.
The term 'ABC Islands' is commonly used in tourism and travel contexts to refer to all three islands, regardless of political differences.
Historical ties between the islands, such as shared colonial past and migration patterns, reinforce their collective identity as ABC Islands.
Political autonomy can influence cultural and economic development, making Aruba distinct enough to be considered separate from Bonaire and Curaçao.
Tourism branding does not override formal political and administrative distinctions between the islands.

supporting.text: The term 'ABC Islands' explicitly includes Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, meaning Aruba cannot be the only one.

attacks.text: The term 'ABC Islands' explicitly includes Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao, meaning Aruba cannot be the only one.
The claim may refer to a colloquial or regional usage where 'ABC Islands' is sometimes used to denote only Aruba in certain contexts.
Historical or political changes might have led to Aruba being the sole recognized member of the ABC Islands in some official capacities.
Colloquial usage is not sufficient to override the widely accepted geographical definition of the ABC Islands.
There is no documented evidence of any official redefinition of the ABC Islands that excludes Bonaire and Curaçao.
Language evolves, and regional colloquialisms can sometimes become more widely accepted than formal definitions.
Official documents or treaties could exist that are not widely publicized but support the claim of Aruba being the only ABC Island.

supporting.text: Culturally and linguistically, Aruba shares many similarities with Bonaire and Curaçao, such as the widespread use of Papiamento, indicating they are part of the same island group.

attacks.text: Culturally and linguistically, Aruba shares many similarities with Bonaire and Curaçao, such as the widespread use of Papiamento, indicating they are part of the same island group.

Geographically, Aruba is located separately from Bonaire and Curaçao, which are closer to each other and to the South American mainland, undermining the claim that they are part of the same island group.
Papiamento is also spoken in other Caribbean islands not considered part of the ABC Islands, so linguistic similarity alone does not define the group.
Despite geographical separation, historical and political ties among Aruba, Bonaire, and Curaçao reinforce their grouping as the ABC Islands.
The ABC Islands are specifically defined by their shared colonial history under Dutch rule, which distinguishes them from other Papiamento-speaking islands.
Historical and political ties are not unique to these three islands; other Dutch Caribbean islands share similar ties but are not included in the ABC Islands.
Colonial history alone is insufficient to define a geographical or cultural island group, as many regions share colonial histories without being grouped together.
